moduleSubtitle: Diabetic Emergencies, Seizures, Stroke, Cardiac, Respiratory, Anaphylaxis, AMS, GI, Genitourinary, Rhabdo, Mental Health, PFA, Environmental Medicine (Complete)

content.content: Diabetes is a chronic condition. The pancreas does not produce enough insulin or the body cannot effectively use the insulin. Insulin is a hormone produced by the pancreas that allows glucose to enter cells. Glucose gives our cells energy. When there isn't enough insulin or cells are resistant to insulin, higher blood glucose levels (BGL) circulate through the bloodstream. Over time, higher BGLs have long-term consequences such as heart and kidney disease, neuropathy, and vision loss. Some people control their diabetes with oral medications and some require insulin medication which is injected below the skin.

Trip participants who have diabetes that requires insulin will have glucometers to monitor their BGLs. A small drop of blood, obtained by pricking the skin with a lancet, is placed on a disposable test strip inserted into the meter. The meter calculates and displays the BGL in mg/dl or mmol/l. Normal ranges are 70-110 mg/dl or 3.9 – 6.1 mmol/l. However, every person is different, each with unique BGL thresholds that work for them.

Hypoglycemia: Defined as BGLs below 70 mg/dl or 3.9 mmol/l, can be due to shivering from cold exposure, increase in exercise levels, increase in carbohydrate intake, and/or too much insulin. Severe hypoglycemia (BGLs below 50 mg/dl or 3.0 mmol/l) is considered a true medical emergency and requires prompt action. Hypoglycemia is on a spectrum that ranges from mild symptoms to unresponsiveness. Some participants may have a medication called glucagon which helps mobilize glucose stores in the liver for cells to use.

Hyperglycemia: Defined as BGLs above 180 mg/dl or 10 mmol/l and can be caused by a decrease in exercise, increase in carbohydrate intake, severe illness and/or low insulin levels. Blood glucose levels can creep up over a period of hours to days. If left untreated, hyperglycemia can become severe, which can lead to diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA) with BGLs above 400 mg/d or significantly higher than a person's normal upper range. DKA occurs when cells have to use fats and proteins for energy because they cannot access sugar in the bloodstream. This leaves ketones as a byproduct in the blood stream, which causes severe illness by dropping the pH of the blood. DKA causes dehydration; if someone can tolerate fluids without vomiting get them to drink unsweetened fluids.

If the patient can swallow, give 15 g of sugar/glucose gel followed by a meal. If the patient cannot swallow, or is unresponsive administer patient's Rx glucagon or roll patient onto their side and place glucose paste between their cheek & gum. Monitor airway. Once AVPU improves and the patient can chew and swallow, have them eat a meal with complex carbohydrates.

NOTE: G in ABCDEG: Any person in a remote backcountry setting that is found unresponsive for unknown reasons should be given sugar between their cheek and gum (while lying on their side to protect their airway).
NOTE: Administering insulin is NOT in a WFR's Scope of Practice.

Trip participants burn more calories in the backcountry especially when recreating at high altitudes and in cold environments. Trip leaders can help prevent low blood sugar for all trip participants, not just those with diabetes, by scheduling several breaks during the day to allow time for snacking in between meals. They should also have glucose gel and/or other quick acting sugar substances readily available while traveling in the backcountry. Individuals who have diabetes should consider bringing 3x their daily preventative Rx medications as a glucagon injection (e.g., Gvoke HypoPen®) or glucagon nasal powder (e.g., Baqsimi®). Some of these medications are temperature sensitive and must be kept cool. It is good practice to separate the Rx medications amongst the trip leaders and the trip participant in case a stash of medicine gets lost or misplaced while traveling.

A seizure is defined as a sudden or transient alteration of normal brain function. The term "seizure" is often used interchangeably with "convulsion." Convulsions are marked by excessive abnormal muscular activity where the person's muscles contract and relax repeatedly. Seizures are rather unpredictable and can be triggered by multiple, uncontrollable factors. Epilepsy is a medical condition characterized by recurrent episodes of seizures. Partial seizures can be subtle since they are contained to one hemisphere of the brain, while general seizures involve both sides of the brain and are usually accompanied by convulsions.

items: Post-ictal stage (brief period of confusion with memory loss of the event)

content.content: NOTE: Some common triggers for seizures in the field are:

items: Missing a dose of a seizure medications
Hormonal change in women (e.g. pregnancy, menstruation, menopause)
Protect their airway if in water
Let the seizure run its course

content.content: A CVA or stroke occurs when either a blood clot becomes lodged in a cerebral blood vessel (ischemic stroke) or a cerebral artery ruptures (hemorrhagic stroke); both mechanisms result in inadequate tissue perfusion of the brain.

The neurological damage due to an ischemic stroke may potentially be reversed with a class of drugs called thrombolytics. Thrombolytic therapy is a treatment that dissolves clots in blood vessels to improve blood flow, and possibly prevent permanent damage to brain tissue. Thrombolytic therapy may be appropriate for certain patients and must be administered within a 4.5 hour window after the onset of symptoms.

The onset of a stroke is sudden and determining a "Last Seen Normal" time from the patient and/or bystanders is very important. Proper wilderness treatment includes accurate assessment, patient comfort, and prompt evacuation.

Aphasia is an impairment of language and is a common presentation in strokes and other brain injuries. Aphasia can present as, 1) the inability to form words and speak, but can understand others, 2) the inability to comprehend language resulting in the presentation of incomprehensible speech or, 3) a combination of both. However, individuals who can comprehend language may be able to communicate in written form.

items: Hemiplegia (paralysis on one side of the body)
Loss of CSM on one side

content.content: NOTE: NEVER give aspirin in the event of a CVA. It will increase bleeding in the brain in the case of a hemorrhagic stroke.

Angina pectoris and myocardial infarction (heart attack) are both caused by coronary artery disease (CAD). CAD is the narrowing of the coronary arteries that supply oxygenated blood to the heart muscle. When the heart muscle does not receive enough oxygen, ischemia occurs.

rows: At rest or with minimal exertion
No relief with rest or nitro
Diaphoresis, nausea, vomiting, SOB, dizziness, AVPU changes

content.content: Sudden cessation of cardiac activity → no pulse. Most common rhythms: VF/VT, asystole, PEA. Follow Chapter 5 CPR/AED guidelines.

Asthma is considered a reactive airway disease where the airway narrows, swells, and produces extra mucous, causing bronchoconstriction and difficulty breathing. There are two types of asthma: allergic (caused by exposure to an allergen) and nonallergic (e.g., caused by stress, exercise, illnesses like a cold or the flu, exposure to extreme weather, irritants in the air, or some medications).

An asthma attack, or "flare-up," is treated using a short-acting bronchodilator delivered via an inhaler (a handheld device that delivers medication straight into the lungs). A "rescue inhaler" is a term used to identify an inhaler containing this class of medication. Albuterol is one of the more common drugs used to treat asthma attacks.
Individuals who have "difficult-to-control" asthma take long-acting bronchodilators or corticosteroids prophylactically as maintenance and control medications to prevent future attacks.
Epinephrine, a potent vasoconstrictor and bronchodilator, is used in an emergency to treat acute, severe asthma attacks when rescue inhalers are no longer effective.

Anaphylaxis is a life-threatening allergic reaction where the immune response described above is much stronger. An overabundance of histamine and other mediators are released to counteract otherwise harmless substances like peanuts (most common), iodine, eggs, milk, insect venom, and certain medications. Anaphylaxis is usually marked by a combination of signs and/or symptoms from two or more body systems.

rows: Hives, welts, redness, itchiness, and swelling of the tongue, lips, and/or throat
Difficulty breathing, and/or swallowing, wheezing, and stridor
Nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, and uterine cramps
Dizziness, fainting, drop in BP and AVPU

items: Inject epinephrine using an auto injector to the lateral aspect of thigh
Repeat injections every 5 minutes if condition worsens and/or every 15 minutes if condition does not improve
The goal is to have the person return to normal BP and breathing
Administer an antihistamine (e.g., Benadryl®, Claritin®, Zyrtec®)
Follow directions on package for dosage and repeat doses until definitive care
Note: Antihistamines will never stave-off anaphylaxis
Consider prednisone or similar drug if evacuation is delayed

content.content: NOTE: Biphasic anaphylactic reactions are rare but can occur hours after the initial reaction. Repeat epinephrine injection if S/Sx return.

Wilderness Medicine Guidelines
An instructor/guide who has been trained in epinephrine administration can help individuals if they believe they are having an anaphylactic reaction.
Follow your state and/or company protocols.
Evacuate individuals who have received epinephrine to definitive care.
Altered mental status (AMS) is a change from a patient's normal baseline behavior or level of responsiveness. AMS can range from mild confusion to coma.
AEIOU-TIPS Mnemonic for Causes of AMS

items: S – Stroke / Shock / Subarachnoid hemorrhage / Sepsis
Check BGL – treat hypoglycemia if present
Evacuate if cause unknown or patient deteriorates

content.content: Any unexplained AMS in the backcountry is a serious finding and warrants rapid evacuation.

A gastrointestinal illness (GI illness) is caused by a pathogen (bacteria, virus, fungus or parasite) that is foreign to an individual and commonly ingested from questionable food and water sources or by poor camp hygiene. GI illnesses can cause a range of unpleasant signs and symptoms from nausea to hypovolemic shock. The job of an outdoor guide/educator is to assess the trip participant, including conducting a focused-exam of the entire abdomen and, based on the subjective and objective information obtained, determine if the pathogen is non-invasive or invasive.

tend to start abruptly with pronounced abdominal pain and cramping followed by profuse diarrhea containing mucous, pus, and blood within hours. Hypovolemic shock sets in rapidly – immediate medical attention is required. Bacillary dysentery, hemorrhagic E-coli, and cholera are some examples.

are self-limiting and start with either nausea and vomiting or painful stomach cramps that get worse before subsiding, typically over 12-48 hours. Acute gastroenteritis, or traveler's diarrhea, and the Norwalk virus are the most common GI illnesses acquired in the backcountry or while traveling abroad.

rows: Mild to moderate abdominal cramping pain that comes in waves and subsides after a bowel movement
Mild to moderate vomiting and dehydration
Pepto-Bismol® may help with some symptoms
Rice, noodles, soup, and other bland foods are good to start eating when nausea and vomiting stops

content.content: Many gastrointestinal illnesses, including the most common pathogens, can be prevented by proper treatment of drinking water in a backcountry setting. There are four methods of treating water: chemical purification, filtration, boiling, and UV light.

Chemical purification works by oxidizing the cellular structure of pathogens. The most common chemicals to treat water are known as halogens, and these include iodine and sodium hypochlorite (household bleach). Many people have iodine allergies, and long term use of iodine is toxic, particularly to the thyroid. Another, arguably better, chemical is chlorine dioxide.

All methods of chemical treatment require a "dwell time," which is the amount of time the chemical must have in contact with a pathogen. In general, the colder and cloudier the water is, a longer dwell time is necessary. Consult the Centers for Disease Control website for specific dwell times and chemical/water ratios.

rows: • Very effective against all waterborne pathogens
• Takes time to boil large amounts of H2O

content.content: Understand the causes and treatment of GI illness and prevention strategies.

items: 1. Differentiate between invasive and non-invasive GI illnesses.
3. Understand the importance of water treatment and the pros/cons of each method.

content.content: The menstrual cycle is the monthly series of changes that an individual's body goes through in preparation for the possibility of pregnancy. Each month, one of the ovaries releases an egg — a process called ovulation. At the same time, hormonal changes prepare the uterus for pregnancy. If ovulation takes place and fertilization of the egg does not occur, the lining of the uterus sheds through the vagina.

Menstruation starts approximately between 9-12 years of age and declines as an individual reaches menopause around age 50. The menstrual cycle, which starts from the first day of one period to the first day of the next, isn't the same for everyone. Menstrual flow might occur every 21 to 35 days, and last two to seven days.
Backcountry trips can cause stress on the body and changes in the menstrual cycle may present as:

items: Mittelschmerz – Pain upon ovulation (LLQ or RLQ pain)

content.content: Ovarian cysts are a common source of pain in premenopausal individuals who are not taking any form of hormonal birth control. These cysts form when the sac that releases the egg does not dissolve. Instead, the sac seals off after the egg is released and fluid builds up inside. Most of these cysts go away after a few weeks. These can grow in size and cause significant pain in the RLQ or LLQ. The A is twisting of the ovary. The client can take analgesics for pain and/or evacuate from the field if the pain is persistent.

An ectopic pregnancy is a life threatening condition that occurs when a fertilized egg implants and grows outside of the uterus, most commonly in the fallopian tube. At approximately 4-8 weeks of pregnancy, the fertilized egg with rapidly dividing cells creates pressure within the fallopian tube and can eventually rupture the tube causing hemorrhage, if not treated. Early detection is lifesaving. Acute pain is felt in either the RLQ or LLQ and eventually, associated internal bleeding. Vaginal bleeding may be present. If suspected, initiate a high priority evacuation. The A is decompensatory hypovolemic shock.
Trip leaders/rescuers may have to ask specific questions to either rule out or obtain more information about a possible genitourinary issue.
Groin pain: Acute or progressive pain in the groin or scrotum.

items: What was your sex assigned at birth?
Do you have external reproductive organs (e.g., testes)?

content.content: Become comfortable enough with genitourinary issues in order to have a conversation with a trip participant in the event an issue arises.

items: 1. Know the differences between urinary tract issues and vaginal infections.
2. Be able to describe a menstrual cycle and the complications that may occur in the field.
3. Know the difference between testicular torsion and epididymitis.
4. Understand the various prevention, Tx, and interventions for each.
Conduct a patient assessment, analyze the information obtained, execute appropriate Tx, monitor interventions and decide on an evacuation plan
Sound judgment and good critical thinking skills when making evacuation decisions

content.content: Rhabdomyolysis (rhabdo) is the rapid breakdown of damaged skeletal muscle tissue resulting in the release of muscle fiber contents (myoglobin) into the bloodstream. Myoglobin is harmful to the kidneys and can lead to kidney failure.
Common causes in the backcountry include overexertion (especially in heat), crush injuries, compartment syndrome, and certain medications/statins.

items: Muscle pain, weakness, stiffness (especially lower extremities)
Aggressive oral hydration (aim for clear urine)
Evacuate – any suspected rhabdo is a medical emergency

content.content: Dark urine + severe muscle pain after exertion = RHABDO until proven otherwise

PTSD is a stress response to an event that triggers physiological and psychological symptoms. A prior stressful event or series of events can cause PTSD. Symptoms often include trouble sleeping, anxiety, panic attacks, avoidance of situations like the stressful event, lethargy, nightmares, and flashbacks. Some events may trigger a person's PTSD, such as being in a situation that is perceived as uncontrollable for them or is similar to the trigger event of their PTSD. It is helpful to remember that for a new participant the perception of risk of an activity may be quite a bit higher than the actual risk.

Depression is a mood disorder in which a person suffers from a prominent and persistent depressed mood that can interfere with daily function. A person is considered to have an episode of depression when several symptoms occur together at one time.

items: Loss of interest in normal activities
Physical agitation or physical slowing down
Complaints of slowed thinking or impaired concentration
Rarely, the patient may become psychotic and/or violent
Assess the need and urgency of evacuation

content.content: ADHD is a cognitive disorder that causes a person to be easily distractable, inattentive, hyperactive, agitated, impulsive, lose important objects, or have concentration difficulties. These behavioral patterns may lead participants to want to begin activities prior to receiving full safety training.

Potential complications in an extended backcountry setting: Most common medications to treat ADHD are stimulants, and when mixed with antidepressants can cause serotonin syndrome. This would most likely happen if participants shared medication, not when someone already arrived on both medications.

A person suffering from a panic attack will often report a sense of imminent danger or doom, shortness of breath, feel a need to escape, experience palpitations, sweating, trembling, chest pain or discomfort, dizziness, nausea, and/or a feeling of "losing it." It can be difficult to differentiate a panic attack from a cardiac or respiratory issue. However, a panic attack will usually resolve itself within 30–60 minutes and a careful OPQRST history of the patient or those close to them will usually reveal a previous history of panic attacks. It is important to remove the person from any identified triggers if possible.

Serotonin syndrome may result if serotonin levels in the body become too high. This usually results early during treatment with an anti-depressant medication (mainly SSRI and SNRI medications – see medication chart) or when the dosage of a current medication is increased or another one added. However, it may also occur when other Rx or OTC medications or recreational substances increase serotonin levels when combined with anti-depressant medications. Commonly, these substances might be cocaine, ecstasy, amphetamines (including ADHD medications), LSD, St. John's Wort, migraine medication, cold medications containing dextromethorphan, ginseng, non-steroidal anti-inflammatory medications such as Ibuprofen and other medications used to control pain.
Most cases of serotonin syndrome present within 24 hours of treatment initiation, dosage increase or when adding new OTC medication or supplements.

items: Discontinue any recreational or herbal substances
Treat fever as per heat illness protocols

content.content: Note: It is not in a WFR's SOP to alter anti-depressant medication doses.

Psychological First Aid (PFA) is an evidence-informed approach for assisting people in the aftermath of disaster and terrorism. PFA is designed to reduce the initial distress caused by traumatic events and to foster short- and long-term adaptive functioning and coping.
8 Core Actions of Psychological First Aid

items: 4. Information Gathering: Current Needs and Concerns

content.content: Special Considerations for All Mental Health Conditions

items: Pre-Trip Discussion: Have a discussion with trip participants who are taking psychotropic medication about their illness and how the trip leaders can best support them and to devise a plan for any symptomatic episodes.
Medications: Consider carrying back-up medications with someone else and waterproofing all medications.

Field discontinuation of medication/recreational substances: Psychotropic or recreational medication should not be discontinued in the field abruptly. Severe discontinuation problems and/or withdrawal can occur. Alcohol and benzodiazepines can have significant withdrawal consequences including seizures and death. These are often delayed 1-3 days and so the person who arrives on a backcountry endeavor with intention to get clean is a red flag.

content.content: Dehydration occurs when fluid loss exceeds fluid intake. Common causes in the backcountry include heavy sweating, inadequate fluid intake, vomiting, diarrhea, and increased respiratory losses at altitude or in cold/dry air.

items: Stop activity and rest in shade
Oral rehydration with water + electrolytes (sports drink, oral rehydration salts)
500–1000 ml/hour until urine is pale and plentiful
Cool the patient (remove layers, fan, wet skin)
Evacuate if unable to drink, persistent vomiting, or altered mental status

content.content: Hyponatremia occurs when excessive water intake dilutes serum sodium, often combined with sodium loss through sweat. Common in long, hot events when participants over-hydrate with plain water.
Mild hyponatremia can rapidly progress to life-threatening cerebral edema and seizures.

items: Give salty foods or hypertonic saline (3% NaCl) if available and protocol allows
Rapid evacuation for any altered mental status, seizures, or vomiting

content.content: Painful muscle spasms, usually in legs or abdomen, after heavy sweating and inadequate electrolyte replacement.
Tx: Rest, gentle stretching, oral electrolytes, salty foods

items: Normal or slightly elevated core temp (<40°C / 104°F)
Oral rehydration with cool electrolyte drink

content.content: LIFE-THREATENING MEDICAL EMERGENCY. Core temperature ≥40°C (104°F) with CNS dysfunction.
Classic (elderly, chronic illness) vs Exertional (young, active). Exertional often presents with sweating still present.

items: Hot, red skin (may be dry or wet)
Altered mental status → confusion → seizures → coma
2. Begin aggressive cooling: ice packs to groin/axilla/neck, immersion if possible, wet sheets + fanning
3. Cool first, transport second if delay >15–20 min

content.content: Hypothermia is a decrease in core body temperature below 35°C (95°F) due to cold exposure exceeding the body's ability to generate and retain heat.

rows: Shivering, impaired fine motor, confusion, normal or high BP
Intense shivering → stops, altered mental status, muscle rigidity, low BP
No shivering, coma, ventricular fibrillation risk, appears dead

content.content: Patients are not dead until they are warm and dead. Profound hypothermia can mimic death (slow pulse/respirations).

items: Active rewarming: body-to-body contact, hot water bottles to groin/axilla/neck
Light exercise only if fully alert and able
Horizontal position, full insulation including vapor barrier
Hypothermia wrap (burrito): tarp → sleeping pad → sleeping bag → outer tarp
Minimal movement – rough handling can trigger VF
Rapid evacuation – these patients need hospital rewarming

content.content: Freezing of tissue, usually extremities or exposed skin. Ice crystals form in tissue causing cellular damage.
Degrees: 1st (superficial) – pale, waxy, numb; 2nd (partial thickness) – blisters clear fluid; 3rd/4th (full thickness) – hemorrhagic blisters, black necrosis.

items: Remove from cold, protect from refreezing (refreezing causes worse damage)
Rapid rewarming in 40–42°C (104–108°F) water until soft/pliable (15–40 min)
Padding between toes/fingers, loose dry dressings
Rapid evacuation – all frostbite needs hospital evaluation (thrombolytics possible)

content.content: DO NOT rub/snow massage, thaw if refreezing likely, or allow patient to walk on thawed feet.
Prolonged exposure to cold, wet conditions (0–15°C) without freezing. Causes vasoconstriction and tissue damage.

items: Cold, numb, pale → red, hot, painful on rewarming

content.content: Tx: Dry, warm gradually (air dry, NOT hot water), elevate, ibuprofen, no walking if severe
Lightning is a massive electrical discharge. Injuries occur via direct strike, side flash, ground current, or blunt trauma from blast.

items: Cardiac/respiratory arrest (asystole common – good prognosis if CPR started)

content.content: Reverse triage: Treat apparently dead first – asystole from lightning often reversible with immediate CPR.

items: C-spine precautions if fall or thrown
All lightning strike patients need hospital evaluation and cardiac monitoring
Headache + one of: fatigue, GI symptoms, dizziness, sleep disturbance

content.content: Tx: Stop ascent, acetazolamide, descent if severe

items: Ataxia, severe headache, altered mental status, hallucinations
LIFE-THREATENING – descent + dexamethasone + O₂ + Gamow bag
Dyspnea at rest, cough, pink/frothy sputum, crackles
LIFE-THREATENING – immediate descent + nifedipine + O₂ + Gamow bag

content.content: Drowning is death by suffocation after submersion in liquid. Non-fatal drowning is survival (at least temporarily) after submersion.

items: 3. Early ventilation (rescue breathing in water if trained)
5. CPR – chest compressions even if pulse present if unconscious

content.content: Hypothermia common – continue CPR until warm.

items: Lung over-expansion injuries (pneumothorax, arterial gas embolism)
Type I: joint pain (“the bends”), skin mottling
Type II: neuro (numbness, weakness, bladder), pulmonary (“chokes”), shock

content.content: Tx: 100% O₂, horizontal, fluids, rapid evac to recompression chamber (DAN hotline)

Giardia, Cryptosporidium, Hantavirus Pulmonary Syndrome, Rabies, Lyme disease, Plague, Leptospirosis, Tick-borne illnesses – all covered with reservoirs, transmission, incubation, symptoms, and prevention/treatment.
Rabies: Any mammal bite → wound care + consider post-exposure prophylaxis + evac.
